channel.title: New vehicle
channel.description:
Ok I was thinking of switching to a truck.. Right now I drive a 2005 Poniac grand am GT-coupe. Look similar to this one. [img]http://www.autospectator.com/cars/files/images/GT-coupe.jpg[/img] Besides mine is black.
Well I was thinking of getting a truck, maybe one with good gas mileage but 4wd? So maybe a ford ranger? So I am asking all of you, what type of truck in the U.S gets good gas mileage and is 4wd?

item.title: New vehicle
item.dc:creator: @Explisionist Explisionist
item.description:
@Explisionist wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:24, topic:316258”][quote author=Explisionist link=topic=412831.msg3057507#msg3057507 date=1260598477]
Fords were the first cars… They have the most models. I would rather get get a ford ranger 4x4. Or a chevy… I am not looking for something that cost like $40,000… I am looking just for a cheaper truck, that is 4x4, small, and can do good on ice, and snow…
[/quote]

Are you looking at getting a new vehicle or a used one? I bought a 1992 Chevrolet S10 4x4 with an extended cab and a 4.3 V6 for $900 from my uncle, it’s probably worth $1500 and you could get one for that. It’s a very good and reliable vehicle, and easy and cheap to work on too if something happens to it, and it will get you anywhere you need to go.[/quote]
Used… No need for a new one. And I am still looking… Not to many trucks for sale around here when its winter =\

Read full topic

Fords were the first cars… They have the most models. I would rather get get a ford ranger 4x4. Or a chevy… I am not looking for something that cost like $40,000… I am looking just for a cheaper truck, that is 4x4, small, and can do good on ice, and snow…

Are you looking at getting a new vehicle or a used one? I bought a 1992 Chevrolet S10 4x4 with an extended cab and a 4.3 V6 for $900 from my uncle, it’s probably worth $1500 and you could get one for that. It’s a very good and reliable vehicle, and easy and cheap to work on too if something happens to it, and it will get you anywhere you need to go.

item.title: New vehicle
item.dc:creator: @mwiebelhaus mwiebelhaus
item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

Explisionist:

Fords were the first cars… They have the most models. I would rather get get a ford ranger 4x4. Or a chevy… I am not looking for something that cost like $40,000… I am looking just for a cheaper truck, that is 4x4, small, and can do good on ice, and snow…

Im glad that you have done your research: Toyota Tacoma - $15,345; GMC Canyon: 16,985 Honda Ridgeline: $28,450

Shit Vehicles: 2010 Ford Ranger: 17,440

Before you come telling me that a honda, toyota, or GMC that I posted costs $40,000 or that the chart I posted includes every vehicle model ford ever made (because it only included their current line-up) do your homework. Your an idiot, but I guess I should have guessed that by your vehicle choices: go buy your fucking ford and don’t come asking on the forums when you encounter your first problem because I told you so.

Read full topic

item.title: New vehicle
item.dc:creator: @runescape3dude runescape3dude
item.description:
@runescape3dude wrote:

[quote=“mwiebelhaus, post:19, topic:316258”][quote author=runescape3dude link=topic=412831.msg3054976#msg3054976 date=1260390850]

Guys, im sure he wants something reliable too, so lets stop with talking about ford unless he likes replacing half of the parts in the vehicle after 100k miles.

http://www.gmc.com/canyon/canyon/index.jsp
http://www.chevrolet.com/colorado/
http://www.toyota.com/tacoma/
http://automobiles.honda.com/ridgeline/

So you recommend Honda? pff
[/quote]

So you recommend ford PFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFFF!. If I had to rate vehichles based on the unreliablity ford would be number UNO!!! If it was the other way around it would be any of the ones I mentioned at the top.

Looka here http://blogs.edmunds.com/strategies/Reliability.jpg Take a look at the top: honda toyota. take a look at the spectrum ford has for less reliablity to more reliable. At least with other car companies you know what the fuck you are getting.[/quote]

Depends on the environment you live in. Over here in NZ hondas are piles of shit (The motorbikes are really good).

Read full topic

item.title: New vehicle
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Just to add a little actual experience to the conversation. I just spent today helping my friend pull his broken-down ford over to have it fixed in Indiana. His toyota was dragging the ground when we hooked only the trailer up to it (no car even), so I had to pull the trailer with ford over to Indiana for him with my Chevrolet. Haha.

Read full topic

I doubt that is true, and I would definitely not go ford. What I would do is get an older Chevy or dodge, I know from experience that they are excellent vehicles. Even fords are fairly good if you go back to the 70s or before.

item.title: New vehicle
item.dc:creator: @Explisionist Explisionist
item.description:
@Explisionist wrote:

Well, I only need 4x4 during the winter, or when it rains… And since I live in Missouri, it seems to be really snowy here… Or really wet… But I guess I will just have to look for something good… If gas wasn’t so high I wouldn’t worry about it… But if I can’t find something that won’t slide and has good gas mileage then oh well… I will just find the 4x4 vehicle.

Read full topic

item.title: New vehicle
item.dc:creator: @runescape3dude runescape3dude
item.description:
@runescape3dude wrote:

2008 Ford Ranger 3.0D TDi XL 180HP 350Nm torque , 8-9L to 100km. Just use the second gear lever to shove it into 4wd(High and Low). Has a button for disengaging the front wheels in the cab.

You’ll probably want the one with bullbars, winch and farmers deck. I will get a picture of the one I drive in the weekend.

Also, these are really easy to change gears in, you can be as rough as you want and it won’t jump all over the place because of it’s weight. (Unlike those damn little Toyota Yaris’s doing bunnyhops when you want to get from 0-100kmh really quickly)

Read full topic

item.title: New vehicle
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Explisionist, post:3, topic:316258”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=412831.msg3042150#msg3042150 date=1259193067]
You are not going to get anything that is 4wd AND gets good gas mileage. Example are 2 identical trucks my brother and I used to have, his was a 90 S10, mine was a 89 S10. Everything was the same, same transmission, same engine, the only difference is that mine was 4 wheel drive and his was just 2 wheel drive. Oh, and mine got 14-15 mpg while his got 21mpg.
[/quote]
=\ whats the closest I can get to having both?[/quote]

That is the closest you can get.

AWD is not 4WD, at all. With AWD it is still possible to get stuck with only 1 wheel spinning, with 4WD you are at least guaranteed that one of your front and one of your rear wheels will spin at the same rate.

Unhandled:

Can’t you get vehicles that have AWD/4WD enabled manually? My dad’s truck is 2WD but it has a switch to change to 4WD.

Of course, my S10 had this as well. Problem is the tires moving are still spinning the front axles regardless of whether it is engaged in the transmission or not. Some (mostly older) vehicles have locking hubs that allow you to disengage the front axles from the wheels by getting out of your vehicle and physically turning a knob on each wheel, but most people just leave them engaged all the time regardless. No matter what a 4x4 is going to have more rolling resistance than a 2x4 and therefore less gas mileage.

And I’m not saying it’s not worth it, depending on where you live, but you won’t get as good of gas mileage as with a comparable 2x4 vehicle.

Read full topic
